metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 78-80, 93 and 152 of 1956 v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Pursuant to resolutions passed by legislatures of several States under Art. 252(1), Parliament enacted Prize Competitions Act, 42 of 1955, brought into force on April 1, 1956 by notification dated March 31, 1956.
Petitioners are engaged in promoting and conducting prize competitions in different States and filed petitions under Art. 32 questioning validity of provisions of the Act and rules.

Section 2(d) defines 'prize competition' as any competition in which prizes are offered for solution of puzzle based on building up, arrangement, combination or permutation of letters, words or figures.

Sections 4 and 5 restrict promotion/conduct of prize competitions: no prize competitions with total prizes exceeding Rs.1000/month or more than 2000 entries; licence required for those <= Rs.1000/month.
Rules 11 and 12: Entry fee max Re.1 or less based on prize value, paid in money only; maintenance of register, accept only first 2000 entries, refund excess.
Genesis in Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act (Bom. LIV of 1948), initially for Bombay, extended by Act XXX of 1952 to competitions outside but operating inside Bombay.
Promoters shifted activities to neighbouring States like Mysore to evade Bombay Act.
Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ, Dixit J) upheld licensing but struck down tax under Art. 301; against that decision Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1956.
States including Bombay passed resolutions under Art. 252(1) authorizing Parliament to legislate on control and regulation of prize puzzle competitions.
Petitions heard along with Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1956; in that appeal, Court held gambling is not trade within Art. 19(1)(g) or Art. 301.

legal_issues.text: Whether 'prize competition' as defined in s.2(d) includes only competitions where success does not depend to any substantial degree on skill (gambling) or also those involving substantial skill.
Whether ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 impose reasonable restrictions under Art.19(6) on skill-based competitions protected by Art.19(1)(g).
Whether impugned provisions are severable, so valid as to gambling competitions even if void as to skill-based ones.

petitioner_arguments.text: Definition in s.2(d) includes competitions depending substantially on skill; conditions in ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 unworkable, encroach on right to carry on business under Art.19(1)(g), unreasonable and prohibitory not regulatory.
Even if reasonable for gambling, not for skill-based; Act single inseverable enactment, fails in entirety.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Severability principle; Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh; Romesh Thappar; Chintaman Rao

respondent_arguments.text: Definition in s.2(d) properly construed means only competitions where success does not depend substantially on skill, i.e., gambling; gambling not trade/business under Art.19(1)(g).
Even if definition wide, provisions severable; valid for gambling competitions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Severability; F.N. Balsara; United Motors; In re Hindu Women's Rights

respondent_arguments.text: Restrictions not reasonable for skill-based (conceded on record).

court_reasoning.text: Following Civil Appeal 134/1956, gambling competitions not protected by Art.19(1)(g); no need to consider reasonableness for them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gambling is res extra commercium, not trade.

court_reasoning.text: Skill-based are business under Art.19(1)(g); respondent concedes restrictions not saved by Art.19(6).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions ex concessi void for skill-based.

court_reasoning.text: History (Bombay Act, evasion, resolutions post-Bombay HC) shows Act intended only for gambling competitions; 'control' indicates gambling, not skill.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Literal construction not conclusive; consider aim, scope, history per Heydon's case, Bengal Immunity.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming s.2(d) includes skill-based, impugned provisions severable; valid parts independent, complete scheme for gambling; legislature would have enacted for gambling knowing skill part invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Severability applies whether invalidity from competence or constitutional prohibitions; gambling and skill distinct categories.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Punjab v. Daulat Singh (indivisible subject), Romesh Thappar, Chintaman Rao (inseverable provisions); follows Balsara, United Motors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Form not substance; substance shows separability.

holdings.text: Prize Competitions Act applies only to competitions where success does not depend substantially on skill (gambling).
Impugned ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 void as to skill-based competitions but severable and valid as to gambling competitions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1956 (Bombay Lotteries case)
precedents_cited.relevance: Gambling not trade under Art.19(1)(g), Art.301.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles of statutory interpretation considering history, mischief.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsara
precedents_cited.relevance: Severability applies even for constitutional prohibitions; medicinal preparations severable.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Severability in enforcement for taxing statutes, general principle.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act
precedents_cited.relevance: Presume legislature intends intra vires; severability if separable.
No severability where subject indivisible; not applicable here.

Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh

statutes_cited.name: Prize Competitions Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition, licensing restrictions, rules; impugned provisions valid for gambling competitions.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental right to trade; reasonable restrictions; writ jurisdiction; parliamentary power.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948 (Bom. LIV)
statutes_cited.relevance: Genesis; licensing valid, tax invalid under Art.301.

outcome.summary: Petitions challenging validity of Prize Competitions Act, 1955 ss.4,5 and rules 11,12 dismissed; provisions held valid and enforceable only qua gambling prize competitions as severable from skill-based ones; Act intended for gambling per history.

key_quotes.text: Gambling is not trade but res extra commercium, and does not fall within the purview of Art.19(1)(g).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on gambling not protected as business.

key_quotes.text: The competitions which are sought to be controlled and regulated by the Act are only those competitions in which success does not depend to any substantial degree on skill.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of s.2(d) based on legislative history.

key_quotes.text: When a statute is in part void, it will be enforced as regards the rest, if that is severable from what is invalid.
key_quotes.speaker: court
